greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of compositions of n having exactly k parts equal to 1.
comment: T(n,k) is also the number of length n bit strings beginning with 0 having k singletons. Example: T(4,2)=3 because we have 0010, 0100 and 0110. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Sep 21 2008

The cyclic version of this array is A320341(n,k), which counts the (unmarked) cyclic compositions of n with exactly k parts equal to 1, with a minor exception for k=0. The sequence (A320341(n, k=0) - 1: n >= 1) counts the (unmarked) cyclic compositions of n with no parts equal to 1. - _Petros Hadjicostas_, Jan 08 2019
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened
D. Baccherini, D. Merlini and R. Sprugnoli, Level generating trees and proper Riordan arrays, Applicable Analysis and Discrete Mathematics, 2, 2008, 69-91 (see p. 83). [_Emeric Deutsch_, Sep 21 2008]
Milan Janjić, Words and Linear Recurrences, J. Int. Seq. 21 (2018), #18.1.4.
formula: If the triangle's columns are transposed into rows, then T(n,k) can be interpreted as the number of compositions of n+k having exactly k 1's. Then g.f.: ((1-x)/(1-x-x^2))^(k-1) and T(n,k) = T(n-2,k) + T(n-1,k) - T(n-1, k-1) + T(n, k-1). Also, Sum_{j=1..n} T(n-j, j) = 2^(n-1), the number of compositions of n. - _Gregory L. Simay_, Jun 28 2019
maple: G:=(1-z)/(1-z-z^2-t*z+t*z^2): Gser:=simplify(series(G,z=0,15)): P[0]:=1: for n from 1 to 14 do P[n]:=coeff(Gser,z^n) od: for n from 0 to 13 do seq(coeff(t*P[n],t^k),k=1..n+1) od; # yields sequence in triangular form
T:= proc(n) option remember; local j; if n=0 then 1
else []; for j to n do zip((x, y)-> x+y, %,
mathematica: CoefficientList[CoefficientList[Series[1/(1 - a), {x, 0, nn}], x], y] // Flatten (* _Geoffrey Critzer_, Dec 23 2011 *)
xref: Column 0 yields A000045 (the Fibonacci numbers). Column 1 yields A006367. Column 2 yields A105423. Row sums yield A011782. Cyclic version is A320341.
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 07 2005
